title: Hybrid war targets business
text:
A recent paper by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute’s Dr Samantha Hoffman, titled Engineering global consent: The Chinese Communist Party’s data-driven power expansion, outlines the extent the Chinese government’s tech-enhanced surveillance is expanding globally.

In the report, Dr Hoffman says China’s efforts don’t revolve around obvious technology such as surveillance cameras, in countries outside China, but through useful technologies such as 5G and, potentially, smartphones.

She said these “services are designed to bring efficiency to everyday governance and convenience to everyday life”.

“The problem is that it’s not only the customer deploying these technologies – notably those associated with ‘smart cities’, such as ‘internet of things’ (IoT) devices – that derives benefit from their use. Whoever has the opportunity to access the data a product generates and collects can derive value from the data. How the data is processed, and then used, depends on the intent of the actor processing it,” she says in the report.

In the report, she uses the example of Global Tone Communications Technology Co. (GTCOM) as a case study to illustrate how the global expansion of the party’s tech-enhanced authoritarianism can work.

For starters, GTCOM is a subsidiary of a Chinese state-owned enterprise that the Central Propaganda Department directly supervises. It openly co-operates with the state’s intelligence services and strategically co-operates with large Chinese firms such as Huawei and Alibaba Cloud.

According to AustCyber chief executive officer Michelle Price, it would be wise for Australian business to be alert to businesses that have been flagged to having close ties with organisations such as GTCOM.

“There’s enough global competition out there that companies going through their procurement processes should be asking more questions around cyber risk,” she says.

“A more mature approach to risk management would involve more due diligence around cyber risk but not all local organisations are building those questions in their risk management approach.

Ms Price says Australian organisations need to immunise themselves against malicious cyber activity and this will involve getting the right sort of policy settings out of federal government.

Australia needs a mature approach to cyber security says Michelle Price, chief executive of AustCyber. Peter Braig

“While there has been lots of investment on the national security side of the coin, more needs to be done on the economic side.”

In recent years, a whole range of countries have developed offensive cyber capabilities as well as defensive strategies and Ms Price says it’s very much the “normal trajectory of how technological development occurs”.

“Cyber is just the latest field being developed for strategic advantage and we’re seeing an increasing number of nation states using cyber tools as part of a hybrid war.”

While much of the more nefarious cyber activity is often the work of cybercriminal networks, Ms Price warns we’re also seeing more nation states accessing bank details and changing business invoices, for example, in a bid to undermine trust in economies.

She says the biggest threats are to supply chains and value chains in business and this is where organisations really have to be alert to cyber risks.

As for individuals, she suggests all Australians need to be aware of cyber risk and “look after their data”.
description: Australian business and government need to be better immunised against malicious cyber activity.
